DOUBLE PENDULUM

In physics and mathematics, in the area of dynamical systems, a double pendulum is a pendulum with another pendulum attached to its end, and is a simple physical system that exhibits rich dynamic behavior with a strong sensitivity to initial conditions. The motion of a double pendulum is governed by a set of coupled ordinary differential equations and is chaotic.

DERIVATIONS

We assume that the rods are massless. Their lengths are l1 and l2. The point masses (they are represented by the balls of finite radius) are m1 and m2. All pivots are assumed to be frictionless.

We introduce the xy-coordinate system, the origin O of which coincides with suspension point of the upper pendulum. The coordinates of the pendulums are defined by the following relationships:

\(x1 = l1sinα1\)

\(x2 = l1sinα1 + l2sinα2 \)

\(y1 = −l1cosα1\)

\(y2 = − l1cosα1 − l2cosα2\)

Kinetic energy of the pendulums :

\(T = {m1v1^2}/2 + {m2v2^2}/2 = m1[{˙x1^2+˙y1^2}]/2 + m2[{˙x2^2+˙y2^2}]/2\)

Potential energy of the pendulums :

\(V = m1gy1 + m2gy2\)

Then the Lagrangian can be written as

\(L = T – V =T1+T2 − {V1+V2} = m1{˙x1^2+˙y1^2}/2 + m2{˙x2^2+˙y2^2}/2 − m1gy1 − m2gy2\)

Take into account that

\(˙x1=l1cosα1⋅˙α1, ˙x2=l1cosα1⋅˙α1+l2cosα2⋅˙α2,\)

\(˙y1=l1sinα1⋅˙α1, ˙y2=l1sinα1⋅˙α1+l2sinα2⋅˙α2\)

Consequently,

\(T1 = {m1 (˙x1^2+˙y1^2)}/2 = {m1(l1^2˙α1^2cos^2α1+l1^2˙α1^2sin^2α1)}/2 = {m1l1^2˙α1^2}/2\)

\(T2= m2 (˙x2^2+˙y2^2)/2 ={m2 [(l1˙α1cosα1 + l2˙α2cosα2)^2 + (l1˙α1sinα1+l2˙α2sinα2)^2]}/2 \)

\( = {m2 [l1^2˙α1^2cos^2α1+ l2^2˙α2^2cos^2α2 + 2l1l2˙α1˙α2cosα1cosα2 + l1^2˙α1^2sin^2α1 + l2^2˙α2^2sin^2α2+ 2l1l2˙α1˙α2sinα1sinα2]}/2 \)

\( = {m2 [l1^2˙α1^2 + l2^2˙α2^2+ 2l1l2˙α1˙α2cos(α1−α2)]}/2\)

\(V1 = m1gy1 = −m1gl1cosα1 \)

\(V2 = m2gy2 = −m2g(l1cosα1 + l2cosα2)\)

As a result, the Lagrangian of the system takes the following form:

\(L = T – V = T1 + T2 − (V1+V2) = (m12 + m22)l12˙α12 + m22 l22˙α22 +m2l1l2˙α1˙α2cos(α1−α2) + (m1+m2)gl1cosα1 + m2gl2cosα2 \)

Now we can write the Lagrange equations

\(d/dt {∂L/∂˙αi} − ∂L/∂αi = 0, i = 1,2. \)

The partial derivatives in these equations are expressed by the following formulas:

\(∂L/∂˙α1 = (m1+m2)l1^2˙α1 + m2l1l2˙α2cos(α1−α2)\)

\(∂L/∂α1 = −m2l1l2˙α1˙α2sin(α1−α2) − (m1+m2)gl1sinα1\)

\(∂L/∂˙α2 = m2l2^2˙α2 + m2l1l2˙α2cos(α1−α2)\)

\(∂L/∂α2 = m2l1l2˙α1˙α2sin(α1−α2) − m2gl2sinα2\)

Hence, the first Lagrange equation can be written as

\(d/dt [(m1+m2) l1^2˙α1 + m2l1l2˙α2cos(α1−α2)] + m2l1l2˙α1˙α2sin(α1−α2) +(m1+m2)gl1sinα1=0\)

\(⇒(m1+m2) l12¨α1 + m2l1l2¨α2cos(α1−α2) + m2l1l2˙α2^2sin(α1−α2) +(m1+m2)gl1sinα1=0 \)

Cancelling \(l1≠0\), we obtain:

\((m1+m2)l1¨α1 + m2l2¨α2cos(α1−α2) + m2l2˙α2^2sin(α1−α2) + (m1+m2)gsinα1=0\)

Similarly, we derive the second differential equation:

\(d/dt [m2 l2^2˙α2 + m2l1l2˙α1cos(α1−α2)] − m2l1l2˙α1˙α2sin(α1−α2) + m2gl2sinα2 = 0\)

\(⇒m2 l2^2¨α2 + m2l1l2¨α1cos(α1−α2) − m2l1l2˙α12sin(α1−α2) + m2gl2sinα2 = 0\)

After cancelling \(m2l2\) ≠ 0 the equation takes the form

\(l2¨α2 + l1¨α1cos(α1−α2) − l1˙ α1^2sin(α1−α2) + gsinα2=0\)


Thus, the nonlinear system of two Lagrange differential equations can be written as:

\((m1+m2)l1¨α1 + m2l2¨α2cos(α1−α2) + m2l2˙α2^2sin(α1−α2) + (m1+m2)gsinα1 = 0\)

\(l2¨α2 + l1¨α1cos(α1−α2) − l1˙α1^2sin(α1−α2) + gsinα2 = 0\)
